titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Weather warm. Messrs: Perkins and Russell dined with us and set out afterwards for Rotterdam. At the french play of the Coffee house. Dupuis et Desronais, and le souper des Jacobins—inferior to mediocrity.

2. Went with Mr: Reutenswerd, Midleton, Brito, the Bielfeld’s, and Mr: Parker to see a collection of paintings belonging to a Gentleman from Antwerp. It contains a number of very good pictures, the most remarkable a Mary with an infant Christ, by Corregio, very much admired, and which he values at 4000 guineas.— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.

3. Breakfasted at Mr: Levsen’s, with Mr: Brito. from thence, went to see the Gardens of the Comte de Bentinck van Rhoon. Better than the generality of Dutch Gardens. On returning home, found a Letter from Mr: Johnson, and English papers, to the 25th: of last month. Reading all the afternoon.
4. Walk in the wood this morning. The two Messrs: Bielfeld Mr: Levsen, & Mr: Brito dined with us. Walk to Schevening after dinner. Evening at Madam Dumas’s. Saw Madam Veerman there.

5. Walk in the wood, which is very much injured by a worm; I suppose it to be the cankerworm. Met and walk’d with Messrs: Levsen & Brito. Received 2 Letters this afternoon from the Secretary of State. News arrived here of the Ratifications of the late Treaty having been exchanged at Paris. Guns fired, rejoycings not very vehement.

6. Visit from Mr: Plaat: complains of the dulness of business. Met in my walk Mr: Brito and Mr: Idibarri the Spanish Gentlemen. walked with them. Wrote the Secretary of State. Reading all the afternoon. Weather very warm. Thunder shower. Leaves the air heavier than it was before. Walk in the Evening. Dull.

7. Letters to England and America. Walk in the morning and towards night. Met Messrs: Midleton & Brito in the forenoon, and the latter also in the afternoon. Much Company in the wood. Walk in the Garden of the Old Court. Visit this morning from Monsr: de Trappe. In the Evening from Mr: Parker. Conversation on the subject of Music.

8. Weather fine. Walk in the wood this morning. Saw nobody.— Rejoycings for the conclusion of the Alliance with France. Parade of the armed militia. Met Messrs: Midleton & Brito.— At Mr: Veerman’s: found them all going to the Ball. Illuminations at the New Doele, and at the house, where the Society meet.

9. Met Mr: Midleton & Mr: Brito in the wood & walked with them. Saw also the Baron de Schubart. At the french play this Evening, Azemia ou les Sauvages. L’heureuse decade. Indifferent. Saw Comte de Löwenhielm.

10. Writing all the morning. Walk towards night. Met M. Brito & the Messrs: Bielfeld. latter returned Monday from Amsterdam. With them till late. Sauntering in the Garden of the old Court & elsewhere.

11. Walk in the wood. met Mr: Levsen. Dined at Count Löwenhielm’s. usual diplomatic company. The Generals Moreau and Dumonceau, with their Aids. Moreau is among those who have no mean opinion of themselves. Simple in dress and manners, clever like almost all his countrymen, with the dash of vanity which seems to be among them, as much a principle as it is a passion. Dumonceau is a Brabanter and has some modesty. Walk with Messrs: Midleton, & the Bielfelds’. Latter part of the Evening at Mr: Veerman’s— Conversation with Madam.

12. At the french play there was what they call a Grand Gala in honour of the alliance lately concluded. Could not go. Mr: Hichborn called to see me. Conversed with me a couple of hours. More frenchman than ever.— Met Mr: Levsen, & Mr: Uribarri, the Spaniard, walking in the wood before dinner.

13. Called on Mr: Hichborn this morning at the Marechal de Turenne, couple of hours more conversation with him. Confirmed in my opinion as to his politics. At the play at Night. La Belle Esclave, miserable. Les Visitandines, a charming Opera & tolerably performed. Satyrical upon convents, Nuns, friars & Religion in general. Of course Revolutionary.— Went with Brito to the Vauxhaull. a single illuminated alley in a Garden, where it was too cold to walk: and a large hall where smoking, drinking, walking and dancing were all going on at once, very much sans façon. stay’d quite late.

14. And therefore late up this morning. Met Mr: Brito in my walk in the morning, & again at Night, as also the brothers Bielfeld in the Evening. Walk in the Garden of the old Court.— Reading,—I say not what.

15. Walk alone before dinner. At night met Brito & the brothers. Saw the burgers exercise, making preparations for more illuminations and fireworks of rejoycing. At Mr: Veerman’s. He came home twice. Madam Dumas, was likewise there.

16. Walk in the wood before dinner. Met Mr: Midleton. In hopes it would rain. Called on Bielfeld, who is unwell. Between 5. and 6. at Mr: Veerman’s. Walk with Madam to Scheveling. The nephew Louis, kept us company. Walk on the downs. Sought the spot of a former visit many years since, recollected with a sort of pleasure. Walk round the town on returning. Found Madam Dumas at the House: and the Officer in quarters.

17. Mr: Bourne called to see me in the morning. Sermon &c in celebration of the Alliance with France. I do not understand the language, & did not hear the sermon. Walk in the morning. After noon, a military parade on the square just out of the town. the french troops, Swiss regiments & burger militia exercised together, & passed in review before the Representatives. The latter wore a large three coloured ribband with the words Representant Vaut Volk van Holland, printed upon the white stripe.— Met Mr: Bourne with Mr: & Madm van Dam, whom he presented to me. Mr: W. Willink, Mr: Mersen, &c &c. At about 7. the parade finished; went to the play, Quatre Coins—Les Visitandines. From thence to Mr: Veerman’s with him, & Madam, & Mr: Masézi the officer went to see the fireworks on the pool opposite the palace. The fireworks did not begin till midnight. In the mean time we stood under the trees of the Vyverberg looking at the Illuminations. The collection of People was numerous, but there were no effusions of joy. All was silence, and although the fireworks
were well executed and the music moving round the island illuminated in the center of the pool, was delightful, scarce a plaudit was heard from the shore. We went from thence to the Vauxhall, crowded with people of every description except the gens comme il faut. Stay’d there till four o’clock, and returned home in broad daylight.

18. Late up this morning. Walk before dinner. Solitary. again at night. Went to Scheveling. traversed the downs again. Weather dull, cold, windy. No fishing boats out from Scheveling to be seen; the view cheerless. Returned home, found Mr: Parker. conversation with him on the subject of painting.
19. Called on Bielfeld in the morning. He is very unwell. Walk in the wood. Alone. Weather very cold. Evening, an hour at Mr: Veermans. Conversation with Madam. French Officer arrived. Home early.

20. Letter this morning from Crafts. Walk in the wood. Met Charles Bielfeld. Read Rousseau’s Confession’s. Walk again on the road to Delft towards night. Weather cold; and has been so for several days.

21. Met both Bielfeld’s in the wood this forenoon. Walked there again towards night. Much Company as is usually the case on Sunday evenings during the summer Season: found however no person that I knew. Mr: Brito, called and passed an hour with me this Evening.
22. A flute for idling of time. A Shakespear at Van Cleefs’ & a backgammon board all at once. Walk in the wood. late, and of course alone. Evening an hour at Mr: Veerman’s. Madam Dumas.

23. Met the Bielfelds’, Messrs: Midleton & Levsen in the wood the two former walked with me. Agreeable Letters from America. At Mr: Veerman’s as by appointment. Went with Madam to see the exercise of the militia or national guards. Dull. Walk afterwards in the wood. Conversation interesting enough. Found Veerman at home when we returned; with a violent head-ach.— He always has the headach.
24. Walk in the morning and again at night. Alone— Called on Bielfeld; found him still quite unwell. Brito there; promised me the loan of some books. Evening at home.

25. Writing a few Letters. Walk. Met C. Bielfeld, Democrat more furious than his brother. Says he had rather see the whole french Nation guillotined, than a king there again. Concluded the perusal of the Theatre of Voltaire.— Music in the Evening.

26. Letters from England. Baggage coming at last. Visit from Mr: Moliere. Walk in the Evening. Spent an hour or two with Bielfeld who continues yet unwell; but mending. Can scarce make out to do any thing.
27. Letter from Mr: Beeldemaker. My baggage has arrived at Rotterdam. Walk in the morning, and also towards night. Very busy but to little purpose. Writing to my father.
28. Writing still to my father. Finished the letter. Dined at home alone. Walk in the wood in the afternoon. Evening pass’d at Mr. Moliere’s. Supper. Stay’d late. Time pleasant eno’.

29. My brother went to Rotterdam. Captain Scott called on me, and dined with me. Walk in the evening. Met him, and went round the usual paths in the wood with him. On my return home found all our baggage just arrived from Rotterdam. My brother returned soon after.

30. Very busy in writing yet could scarce make out to do any thing. The instance is not singular. Walk in the Evening. Returning home found a Card from Mr: Quarles the Greffier with a couple of copies of the late Treaty with France. At the play, La Rosiere de Salency and La Soirée Orageuse. The former old. the last tolerable music. Spanish plot. Visit this morning from both Bielfeld’s.
